DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: FRENKEL, L. M.;Frenkel, L. M.;FRENKEL, LUISE MARION;Luise Marion Frenkel

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: é Professora Doutora (MS-3) de Língua e Literatura Grega da Universidade de São Paulo. Com doutorado pela Universidade de Cambridge (Inglaterra) e em Matemática Aplicada pelo IME/USP, é bacharel em Letras - Grego pela FFLCH/USP e em Ciências Moleculares pela USP. Realizou estágios de pesquisa pós-doutoral com bolsa na Escola Britânica de Roma (Itália), USP, Fondation Hardt (Suíça), University of Birmingham (Inglaterra), Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen (Alemanha) e Max-Weber Kolleg (Erfurt, Alemanha), onde também realizou um pós-doutorado em 2017/18. Desde 2015 é pesquisadora visitante no St. Edmund?s College (Cambridge, Inglaterra). É autora de numerosos artigos, capítulos e de um livro sobre a retórica dos discursos de Teódoto de Ancara pela Editora Peeters (Leuven, Bélgica). Em colaboração com grupos de pesquisa internacionais, desenvolve pesquisas interdisciplinares sobre a Antiguidade Tardia, em especial sobre as polêmicas religiosas e sociais do quarto ao sétimo século d.C., a conectividade do Império Romano tardio na África e no Oriente, e o desenvolvimento das ciências, correntes filosóficas e da literatura grega imperial e bizantina, siríaca, copta, árabe e latina. Os temas centrais são as narrativas historiográficas, oralidade, materialidade e os estudos de recepção antiga e moderna. Também prepara a edição crítica de um manuscrito siríaco que preserva um diálogo polêmico grego de V d.C. Tem experiência na área de Línguas e Literaturas Clássicas, com ênfase na Antigüidade Tardia.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Luise Marion Frenkel is Assistant Professor in Classical Greek at DLCV-FFLCH/Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil, since 2013. Since 2012 she has been awarded post-doctoral fellowships at the British School at Rome, DLCV-FFLCH/USP, Fondation Hardt (Switzerland), the University of Birmingham (UK), the Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen (Germany) and the Max-Weber Kolleg (Erfurt, Germany), where she was also a junior fellow in 2017/18. Since 2015 she has been a Visiting Scholar at St Edmund?s College, Cambridge. As a Gates scholar, she received a Ph.D. in Divinity from the University of Cambridge (2007-2012). She also holds a Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics from the Institute of Mathematics and Statistics, USP, Brazil (2003-2007), a B.A. in Classical Greek (2006) and a B.Sc. in Molecular Sciences (2003), both also from USP. In her interdisciplinary research, she explores Late Antiquity, especially the development of oral traditions, historiographic narratives, philosophical schools and of the sciences. Her peer-reviewed articles, chapters and monograph focus on religious controversies and social unrest from the fourth to seventh century CE, narratives of individualisation and institutionalisation, processes of Romanisation and Hellenisation, late-antique networks in Africa and the Indian Ocean and the ancient and modern reception of Latin, Syriac, Coptic, Ge'ez, Arabic and imperial and Byzantine Greek texts. Current projects address migration and mobility in the late Roman Empire in the East, the textual representation of Arab incursions and the critical edition of a Syriac manuscript of a fifth-century Greek dialogue.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Diálogos polêmicos tardo-antigos: edição crítica e comentário
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O objeto da pesquisa são textos gregos do V século d.C. e suas traduções siríacas (V-VI d.C.) relacionados às polêmicas do reinado de Teodósio II. A finalidade é a edição crítica e comentada de manuscritos que preservam tratados e diálogos inéditos (publicação prevista na série CCSG, editora Brepols, Turnhout-BE).
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The research focuses on fifth-century Greek texts linked to the polemics of Theodosius II?s reign ? and their Syriac translations (especially from the fifth and sixth-century). Critical editions and commentaries of manuscripts of still unpublished treatises and dialogues will be published in the series CCSG (Brepols, Turnhout-BE).

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: O problema de Kendall na esfera
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O projeto visa estender o Problema de Kendall, formulado para rolamentos de uma esfera sobre o plano, aos movimentos de uma esfera de raio 1, rolando sem escorregar e sem pivotar sobre geodésicas de uma esfera de raio maior que 1. Mais precisamente, busca determinar quantos movimentos desse tipo são necessários para levar posições prefixadas de referenciais ortonormais de um ponto a outro da esfera maior. Emprega-se para tanto resultados de Teoria de Controle, Cinemática do corpo rígido, Mecânica Hamiltoniana e Lagrangiana, Ângulos de Euler e Sistemas Dinâmicos.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Expand the original ?Kendall?s Problem? which dealt with a sphere moving without slipping and without twisting over an horizontal plane to spheres. The aim is to establish the smallest natural N such that it is possible to take the sphere from an initial state (p, Rp) described according to a positive orthonormal frame attached to its centre to a final state (q,Rq) by a sequence of N movements, in which the sphere is rolling without slipping and without twisting over segments of geodesics on the larger sphere.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: O problema de Kendall na esfera

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Retórica de consenso tardo-antiga: redação e transmissão de atas sinodais e senatoriais
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Este projeto analisa as estratégia de comunicação tardo-antigas para a representação escrita de decisões unânimes. Questionando a relevância dos modelos elaborados nos últimos dois séculos a partir de um conjunto de fontes limitado, o projeto pretende mostrar que as semelhanças estruturais e argumentativas entre as atas e registros sinodais e senatoriais não resultaram de emulação (deliberada) ou imposição de práticas dos Senados (de Roma e de Constantinopla). Os resultados podem ser estendidos para as estratégias tardo-antigas de registro e reinterpretação de demonstrações coletivas de aprovação e desaprovação, e para seu uso na auto-representação de grupos e de seus membros em relação à identidade imperial e às diretrizes de religiões institucionalizadas.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: In the project, the communication strategies employed in late-antique textual representation of unanimous collective decision-making are analysed. It questions the general models extrapolated from a body of select sources taken as a cohesive whole in the last two centuries and aims to show that the similar patterns in synodical and senatorial proceedings were not a (deliberate) emulation or imposition of practices of the Senate Houses (in Rome or Constantinople). The results exemplify the strategies used to record and re-interpret large-scale demonstrations of assent or dissent, and how they were used in the self-representation of groups and its members in relation to imperial identity and the guidelines of institutionalised religion.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Retórica de consenso tardo-antiga: redação e transmissão de atas sinodais e senatoriais

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The project examines the contents, literary articulation and codicological presentation of dialogues and florilegia in which Cyrillian passages predominate. It analyses their contribution to anti-Nestorian invective in Greek, Syriac and Arabic literary communities, relating their reception to the concomitant composition of works in these intellectual cultures.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The project examines the contents, literary articulation and codicological presentation of dialogues and florilegia in which Cyrillian passages predominate. It analyses their contribution to anti-Nestorian invective in Greek, Syriac and Arabic literary communities, relating their reception to the concomitant composition of works in these intellectual cultures.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Historiography of Arab incursions and religious controversies
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The goal is to analyse the communicative processes that enabled seventh-century Greek, Latin, Syriac and Coptic authors to employ the characterisation of violence, destruction, death and damnation consolidated in fourth- and fifth-century writings on Christian polemics to refer to (power) political, economic, administrative, cultural and religious processes, such as the Arab expansion, which are posed as threats, countering propaganda of peace and stability which had gained strength after the end of the Persian might.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The goal is to analyse the communicative processes that enabled seventh-century Greek, Latin, Syriac and Coptic authors to employ the characterisation of violence, destruction, death and damnation consolidated in fourth- and fifth-century writings on Christian polemics to refer to (power) political, economic, administrative, cultural and religious processes, such as the Arab expansion, which are posed as threats, countering propaganda of peace and stability which had gained strength after the end of the Persian might.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Literatura e arqueologia da representação de consenso na Antigüidade Tardia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The proposed research addresses the late-antique narrative resources used to present consensual and unanimous actions in processes of institutionalisation and individualisation in religious contexts, and the changes in the interpretation of the texts during their reception and transmission. My project aims to examine their sociohistorical framework and political function, especially in processes of institutionalisations of the past and of religious or political groups. The focus falls on fifth-century Greek sources which inaugurate the redaction and compilation of proceedings and codes as known in Roman Law and Christian Conciliar Studies. The project also follows the changes in the material and social ideas about codifications and compilations. It engages with theories on Christian and Roman identities, and their development and influence. For example, the seemingly similar proceedings of Christian synods and decision-making sessions of civil institutions in the Roman Empire and their cultural and historical significance will be analysed. Expanding previous work, in part pursued in conjunction with the Kolleg-Forschergruppe ?Religiöse Individualisierung in historischer Perspektive? (KFG) at the Max-Weber-Kolleg (MWK) during a three-months junior fellowship in 2015-16, the project advances the thesis that the written representations of unanimity and consensus are primarily literary creations which contributed tokens of authority to the discourse for which they were composed.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The proposed research addresses the late-antique narrative resources used to present consensual and unanimous actions in processes of institutionalisation and individualisation in religious contexts, and the changes in the interpretation of the texts during their reception and transmission. My project aims to examine their sociohistorical framework and political function, especially in processes of institutionalisations of the past and of religious or political groups. The focus falls on fifth-century Greek sources which inaugurate the redaction and compilation of proceedings and codes as known in Roman Law and Christian Conciliar Studies. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: A tradição retórica clássica em coleções de documentos gregos da Antiguidade Tardia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O objeto da pesquisa são as cartas e discursos compostos na primeira metade do século V d.C. e, daí, transmitidos nas coleções gregas e latinas de documentos conciliares. A finalidade da pesquisa é o estudo dos efeitos retóricos na recepção dos textos, no qual se distinga a recepção imediata e posterior das obras e coleções, ou ainda, o "público original", a que o autor mesmo visou ao compor sua carta ou discurso, e o "público posterior", que o compilador teve em mente ao reunir as obras.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The research topic are letters and speeches composed in the first half of the fifth century A.D., and then transmitted in Greek and Latin collections of conciliar documents. The aim of the research is the study of the rhetorical effects on the reception of the texts, distinguishing the immediate and the later receptions of the works and the collections, that is, the 'original public', addressed by the author when writing his letter or speech, and a 'later public' which the compiler had in mind when assembling the texts.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: A tradição retórica clássica em coleções de documentos gregos da Antiguidade Tardia

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Social Rituals in the Roman World
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Inspired by recent developments in the social scientific study of rituals, we aim to focus on the ritualisation of a number of different aspects of social life. For, arguably, many social spheres or social phenomena (e.g. the economy, social hierarchies, political communities) could hardly function properly without the trust, legitimation or sense of collective identity provided and reinforced by public rituals.In addition to exploring ritual in a wider section of social phenomena than usual in Classics, the breadth of expertise within the centre (archaeology, social, economic, and cultural history) will allow us to expand the range of sources usually adduced. Specific attention will also be dedicated to comparative studies: the Roman Empire was a multicultural and multireligious society, and rituals in one part of the empire or among adherents of one religion should not be presumed to be identical.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Inspired by recent developments in the social scientific study of rituals, we aim to focus on the ritualisation of a number of different aspects of social life. For, arguably, many social spheres or social phenomena (e.g. the economy, social hierarchies, political communities) could hardly function properly without the trust, legitimation or sense of collective identity provided and reinforced by public rituals.In addition to exploring ritual in a wider section of social phenomena than usual in Classics, the breadth of expertise within the centre (archaeology, social, economic, and cultural history) will allow us to expand the range of sources usually adduced. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: As homilias de Teódoto de Ancira e o Concílio de Éfeso (431)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O projeto analisa da construção retórica da auto-representação de bispos e membros da administração imperial em cenários sinodais do quinto-século, em que os concílios lidam tanto com assuntos disciplinares como doutrinais. Estuda a veiculação oral e escrita de sermões, discursos e cartas para angariar apoio, reivindicar que as decisões eram unânimes e difamar oponentes como heterodoxos, excomungados ou corruptos. A pesquisa interdisciplinar histórica, teológica e literária de textos gregos, latinos e etiópicos, e arqueológica da evidência de recintos cristão em Éfeso no início do quinto século acrescenta uma nova dimensão às evidências para os estudos conciliares, que geralmente atem-se às minutas e aos documentos mencionados naquelas.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The project analyses fifth-century historical and theological developments pivotal for the formation of European, Byzantine and Islamic identities. By focusing on sermons of the period of the first Council of Ephesus (431), and placing them in their wider context, new light can be shed on the contributions of individual bishops to a council, illustrating the debates on the nature of Christ which involved several bishops, the Roman Emperors and the highest ranking members of the imperial administration for several decades. The analysis of the use of classical rhetoric in homilies and letters, of the contemporary setting and of the transmission of synodical texts contributes to conciliar studies, a field that tends to restrict itself to a better known but small subset of the sources, namely minutes and the texts mentioned in them. The interdisciplinary approach uses historical, theological, literary approaches to unjustly neglected or belittled texts, and employs the archaeological evidence to contextualise the performance and circulation of discourses.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: As homilias de Teódoto de Ancira e o Concílio de Éfeso (431)

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: Research project on ?The authority of consensus in Late Antiquity: narratives of popular, senatorial and synodical unanimity?, in collaboration with the Kolleg-Forschergruppe "Religiöse Individualisierung in historischer Perspektive"
VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-INGLES: Research project on ?The authority of consensus in Late Antiquity: narratives of popular, senatorial and synodical unanimity?, in collaboration with the Kolleg-Forschergruppe "Religiöse Individualisierung in historischer Perspektive"

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The authority of consensus in Late Antiquity: narratives of popular, senatorial and synodical unanimity
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The proposed research addresses the late-antique narrative resources used to present consensual and unani-mous actions in processes of institutionalisation and individualisation in religious contexts, and the changes in the interpretation of the texts during their reception and transmission. My project aims to examine their sociohistorical framework and political function, especially in processes of institutionalisations of the past and of religious or political groups. The focus falls on fifth-century Greek sources which inaugurate the redaction and compilation of proceedings and codes as known in Roman Law and Christian Conciliar Studies. The project also follows the changes in the material and social ideas about codifications and compilations. It engages with theories on Christian and Roman identities, and their development and influence. For example, the seemingly similar proceedings of Christian synods and decision-making sessions of civil institutions in the Roman Empire and their cultural and historical significance will be analysed. Expanding previous work, in part pursued in conjunction with the Kolleg-Forschergruppe ?Religiöse Individualisierung in historischer Perspektive? (KFG) at the Max-Weber-Kolleg (MWK) during a three-months junior fellowship in 2015-16, the project advances the thesis that the written representations of unanimity and consensus are primarily literary creations which con-tributed tokens of authority to the discourse for which they were composed.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The proposed research addresses the late-antique narrative resources used to present consensual and unani-mous actions in processes of institutionalisation and individualisation in religious contexts, and the changes in the interpretation of the texts during their reception and transmission. My project aims to examine their sociohistorical framework and political function, especially in processes of institutionalisations of the past and of religious or political groups. The focus falls on fifth-century Greek sources which inaugurate the redaction and compilation of proceedings and codes as known in Roman Law and Christian Conciliar Studies. The project also follows the changes in the material and social ideas about codifications and compilations. It engages with theories on Christian and Roman identities, and their development and influence. For example, the seemingly similar proceedings of Christian synods and decision-making sessions of civil institutions in the Roman Empire and their cultural and historical significance will be analysed. Expanding previous work, in part pursued in conjunction with the Kolleg-Forschergruppe ?Religiöse Individualisierung in historischer Perspektive? (KFG) at the Max-Weber-Kolleg (MWK) during a three-months junior fellowship in 2015-16, the project advances the thesis that the written representations of unanimity and consensus are primarily literary creations which con-tributed tokens of authority to the discourse for which they were composed.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Narrativas de unanimidade e diálogo em protocolos sinodais e hagiografias tardo-antigas
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Narrativas de unanimidade e diálogo em protocolos sinodais e hagiografias tardo-antigas

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: I analyse summonses mentioned in letters and proceedings circulated by the majoritarian faction of the Christian leaders gathered in Ephesus in A.D. 431, highlighting its layers of meaning and the aspects of verbal and non-verbal communication to which they refer. I contrast them with the mutual accusations and sanctions, mentioned in letters and pamphlets by imperial officials and faction leaders, which corroborate or weaken the representation of consensus by means of written documents. Thus, I problematise the narrative which purports to meet the imperial injunctions of discussions about religious issues relying on the pattern set at Nicaea, performed in unanimity and dialogue, and secured imperial endorsement of the decisions. This literary and historical analysis of the argumentative purpose of late-antique synodical proceedings corroborates that also in the more extensively documented meetings of ecclesiastic leaders, the representation of the events remains partial, and they cannot be taken as typical representatives of a wider phenomenon. Analysing the reliability of the reports of popular and monastic demonstrations in Constantinople, especially the references to non-verbal communication, contributes to the study of the early circulation of synodical acts.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Individual Christian Voices in the Narratives of Late Antique Acclamations
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Individual Christian Voices in the Narratives of Late Antique Acclamations

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In search of the individual in the late antique reports of acclamations relevant for understanding Christian religious discourse, the article first addresses the fully fledged accounts and surveys the unreliability of the sources as witnesses of the events and of the original impact of the narratives. This aspect comes to the fore when looking at papyri and the epigraphical evidence. Although composed and registered nearer in time to the alleged performances of acclamations, they are likewise unreliable because focused on their reception. In the context of late antique rhetoric and communication strategies, their literary qualities were adequate for a re-performance of the narrative which would reiterate the ritual. Such reception of narratives of acclamations was therefore relevant to an individual construction of traditions and institutions. Finally, the paper discusses homogeneous clusters of religious graffiti, which come out as collective unanimous discourses from the perspective of the viewer, especially when literate. Summing up the aspects of individual reception of the narratives of acclamations and agency of the redactor, the article concludes by demonstrating their importance in processes of religious and political institutionalisation.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Syriac Christological Dialogues and the Transmission of Theodotus of Ancyra’s Contra Nestorium
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Syriac Christological Dialogues and the Transmission of Theodotus of Ancyra’s Contra Nestorium

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This article analyses the context of the Syriac translation of a refutation of Nestorian excerpts attributed to Theodotus of Ancyra and preserved (with lacunae) in Ms. British Library Add. 17,148, and compares the work with the transmission and translation of the texts attributed to him. The article examines the reception of Cyrillian dialogues as a form of anti-Nestorian invective in Greek, Syriac and Arabic literary communities, and discusses the possibly concomitant composition of soghyatha such as that ?of Cyril and Nestorius? in Syriac intellectual cultures.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Peace and Harmony at Church Councils and in the Roman Empire under Theodosius II
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Peace and Harmony at Church Councils and in the Roman Empire under Theodosius II

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
https://doi.org/10.30965/25890433-04801005
Abstract: In fifth-century synods and councils, peace as a value linked to harmony is mentioned mainly in texts linked to the communication between the imperial administration and the bishops. The connection of peace and harmony is not foreign to Christian discourse, insofar as these values are usually expressed in terms that have Scriptural and patristic background related to religious strife to addressees whose identity is prominently Christian. Concurrently, in written communication with imperial officers, the relevance of the issues for the Roman empire and how Roman legislation could be applied to them was at the forefront, and theological or ecclesiastic details were accessory to the argument. In the context of the oral and written discourses and the use of non-verbal communication strategies, the selective appropriation of the elocution proper to the networking with the imperial administration in the core conciliar documentation of minutes and reports contributed to the partiality and incompleteness of the information they convey. Contextualising their rhetoric of peace, shows the influence of the authorial voices in the construction of the narratives.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Anastasius of Sinai?s Reaction to the Islamic Expansion
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Anastasius of Sinai?s Reaction to the Islamic Expansion

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: A história da conquista árabe foi escrita sobretudo por meio da harmonização dos poucos relatos existentes. Neste processo, atentou-se pouco para as estratégias narratológicas e autorais da Antiguidade Tardia. Neste capítulo expõe-se como a retórica polêmica dos conflitos cristãos afetou a representação histórica dos desenvolvimentos políticos e culturais do século VII no norte da África e no Oriente Próximo. Mostra-se aqui as conotações políticas e religiosas da representação historiográfica de invasões e revoltas, um problema contínuo nestas regiões. Para tanto, recorre-se a obras atribuídos a Anastácio Sinaíta e à evidência epigráfica de Chipre que indicam que na transição do domínio romano para o árabe muçulmano predominou continuidade na vida das populações e em sua apreensão do mundo. Mostra-se que as descrições de violência e destruição durante a expansão árabe fazem parte do repertório narrativo desenvolvido durante os séculos IV e V ? presente sobretudo nos textos sobre polêmicas cristãs oriundos da parte oriental do Império Romano ? e expandido pelos lugares-comuns escatológicos, judaizantes e anti-heréticos que se desenvolveram no século VI, quando eram empregados para denegrir inimigos bem como para sistematizar as identidades religiosas da população. (Artigo em inglês.)
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The history of the Arab Conquest has been largely written by harmonising the few extant accounts without addressing late-antique narratological and authorial strategies. This chapter advances that the polemical rhetoric of Christian conflicts affected the historical representation of seventh-century political and cultural developments in North Africa and the Near East. It shows the political and religious overtones of the historiographical representation of the invasions and uprisings in these regions, where they were an ongoing problem. To do so, texts attributed to Anastasius of Sinai and some inscriptions from Cyprus are analysed and show that more continuity than upheaval characterises the transition from Roman to Muslim Arab rule. The narratives of violence and destruction during the Arab expansion are in line with Eastern Roman fourth- and fifth-century writings on Christian polemics, augmented by the sixth-century developments of eschatological, Judaising and anti-heretical narrative commonplaces with which rivals were denigrated, and the complex religious belongings of the population was systematised.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: The imperial identity of senatorial rituals in Late Antiquity
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: The imperial identity of senatorial rituals in Late Antiquity

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Imperial Identities in the Roman World

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The Later Roman Empire of Diocletian and Constantine undoubtedly projected different stories of belonging, different social-ideological models for people to relate to. One possible example might that of the Empire as an idealized military command structure, in which even a civil service career could be viewed as a tour of duty; another more obvious example, post-Constantine, was of course the notion of a Christian oikoumene, of Christendom. Even in the Late Empire, however, earlier Roman rituals of identity might still have a strong legitimating force, albeit in novel and perhaps unexpected contexts, as Luise Marion Frenkel shows in her contribution on senatorial rituals in Late Antiquity. In her chapter, she discusses how typically senatorial modes of deliberation and decision-making rituals inherited from the earlier Roman world not only (still) characterized proceedings in the Senates of Rome and Constantinople, but were also adopted by Christian synods. Through embedding their own decisions in senatorial and imperial deliberative ritual and administrative practice, Frenkel argues, bishops not only sought legitimacy for their own decisions, but also contributed to the further legitimization of imperial power.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Studia Patristica. Vol. XCII - Papers presented at the Seventeenth International Conference on Patristic Studies held in Oxford 2015. Volume 18: Liturgica and Tractatus Symboli; Orientalia; Critica et Philologica; Historica

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The article argues that the similar patterns in synodical and senatorial proceedings were not a (deliberate) emulation or imposition of practices of the Senate Houses (in Rome or Constantinople). Rather, both exemplify some of the communication strategies that allowed collective demonstrations of assent or dissent to be recorded, re-interpreted and used to support, for example, an intended self-representation of Senate, synods and their relation to imperial identity. To do so, it brings together recent results of the research on the late antique argumentative use of supposed verbatim accounts, and the textual representation of unanimous collective decision-making. Thus, it shows that the recur- ring patterns found in their extant proceedings do not point to a genuine similarity between the recorded synodical and conciliar events linked to an emulation of the Roman prototypes by a Christian Church. These often mentioned claims followed from the work of scholars who systematised, for example, Roman and Canon Law, while they elaborated on Reichssynoden, episcopal jurisprudence and a Reichskirche assimilated into the empire since Constantine. They extrapolated, from select sources taken as a cohe- sive whole, general models for the proceedings of what they considered established institutions. However, their schematic representations do not account for the manifold and changeable character of early Christian synods and so-called Church Councils, nor for the procedures adopted at the sessions in the Senate Houses. The article links this to the current picture of regional and diachronic social variations of the working of religious and administrative bodies, and especially to the classical discursive conven- tions and polemic or apologetic character of the proceedings. The models come out of scholarly constructs, which rely on anachronistic or timeless concepts such as democracy, law codes, orthodoxy, papacy and paganism in the broad context of the Roman Empire in Late Ant

The article links this to the current picture of regional and diachronic social variations of the working of religious and administrative bodies, and especially to the classical discursive conven- tions and polemic or apologetic character of the proceedings. The models come out of scholarly constructs, which rely on anachronistic or timeless concepts such as democracy, law codes, orthodoxy, papacy and paganism in the broad context of the Roman Empire in Late Ant

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: Mustering Sources and Vindication: Theodoret of Cyrrhus? Sources and the Models of Greek Ecclesiastical Historiography
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: Mustering Sources and Vindication: Theodoret of Cyrrhus? Sources and the Models of Greek Ecclesiastical Historiography

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Sources et modèles des historiens anciens

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Theodoret?s Historia ecclesiastica (= HE) is a towering achievement of late-antique Greek historiography. It is the work most now associate with him and cite from, yet it has received relatively little scholarly attention and studies dedicated to Theodoret largely overlook it. More than any fourth to seventh-century writer, he left a complete coverage of all major literary genres, in both their classicising and Christian variants, and was furthermore fully integrated in the bilingual Syriac literary environment of his province. However, scholars have focused on a handful of works for their theological importance, on the Historia religiosa (= HR) in the wake of renewed perspectives on hagiography and especially on early Christian asceticism, and recently, with a fresh approach, again on Theodoret?s ecclesiastical and political participation. This chapter cannot remedy the oversight, and in looking at Theodoret?s sources and models, will only indicate some of the literary effects he drew from using them, referring to a literary tradition in the making and defending his concept of imperial rule. It will discuss the contribution of the HE to Theodoret?s literary persona and authorial voice, pointing to his relative failure in the first and success in the second, as reflected by the temporary condemnation of his writings and by his recognition as the fifth- century historian who best understood and problematised the late-antique Roman Empire and whose work used the most elevated and clear style.

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
Lactantius and Eusebius of Cæsarea wrote about a man who was executed for tearing down an imperial writing said to contain the order for the destruction of Christian scriptures. The chapter addresses the relation of their historiographic narratives to the polemical characterisation of imperial authority in topoi about the materiality of writing which reflect various concepts of language. Referring to similar incidents in Greek and Rabbinic literature, the plausibility of the accounts is assessed with regard to fourth- and fifth-century Roman law, the unfolding of the Diocletianic Persecution and the production and reception of traditions about the enforcement of measures against religious practices and groups. The chapter shows that the pas-sages underline the relevance of texts for the imperial identity of the provinces, in Christianity and in the structure of Eusebius? and Lactantius? works. Their stylised accounts would reveal to audiences steeped in the the reception of the Roman literary and political past the contribution of their historiographies as material conveyors of a reasoning which could buttress the imperial and religious identity of their world.

Keywords: Historiography; Book-burning; Roman Empire - maiestas; Eusebius, of Caesarea, Bishop of Caesarea, (Ca. 260-Ca. 339); Lactantius, Lucius Caecilius Firmianus (240?-320
http://hdl.handle.net/10316.2/47268

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: Institutionalisation of tradition and individualised lived Christian religion in Late Antiquity

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Eusebius of Caesarea?s letter CPG 3502 is one of the earliest narratives about the Council of Nicaea (325) that describes procedures and documents used at meet-ings between bishops and the emperor Constantine. This chapter looks at pro-cesses of religious individualisation in the reception of the letter from the fourth to the seventh century and asks which mechanisms of religious pluralisation shaped the transmission of this seminal text for the history of Christianity. It thus questions the context of its twentieth century publication. Analysing also Cyril?s letter CPG 5320, the chapter scrutinises the reliability of the narrative implied by the texts that have usually been regarded as sources for the councils of Nicaea and Ephesus (431). It does this by pointing to the processes of religious individualis-ation that shaped lived Christian faiths and pieties in Late Antiquity. The scope of enforcement of conciliar decisions and the vulnerability of the representativity of the participants will be discussed, situating their actions in the context of the plurality of lived Christian faiths. The chapter also discusses the dynamics of the de-institutionalisation of Roman religious rites in Late Antiquity by examining them in the context of fragmented Christian orthodoxies in which bishops and other religious authorities were vulnerable to accusations, and social upheaval or unrest.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Our chapters suggest that assertions of religious authority are intimately related to processes of pluralisation. Not being able to rely on social or political authority, these claims are competitive. Authority is not simply given but is, rather, based on acceptance, with complex discourses dedicated to establishing its criteria. To start with, rhetorical devices are employed to characterise the status, the reliability and the trustworthiness of the self in ego-narratives (Frenkel, see also Henderson, III.2, and Bashir, II.2). Agency in religious pluralisation is, therefore, found in the creation of narra-tives about the past and its actors, or the description of the characteristics and characters of the present with which new religious practices and concepts, or new combinations of these, can be described as being ancient and traditional, or common, respectively. With different modes of communication, or even of intel-lection, agents of pluralisation try to establish criteria of plausibility for which the tools of enforcement available to political authorities are not sufficient. Phi-losophy tries to establish impersonal criteria, epic narrative contextualises the ?opinions? of individual ?I?s? by a faceless or withdrawn narrator. The reader-ships and audiences, however, know of alternative authorities to those claimed by the texts with which they are confronted (cf. again Henderson and Gordon, IV.1). Different teachers, other saints, and nearby monasteries offer alternatives (Frenkel, see also Ramelli, III.1).

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: With a holistic approach, this study of Ms. British Library Additional 12,150, the earliest dated Christian literary manuscript in any language, looks at the early fifth-century scribal activity, and its relation to the development of the Church of the East, Syriac intellectual cultures and Roman-Sassanid exchanges, while reassessing the distinctiveness of the agency of the few individuals named in the textual evidence. This paper also analyses the reception of the works in the manuscript in late fourth-century Syriac culture, the processes that shaped Syriac Christian cultures during the early fifth century and the reputation of Eusebius of Caesarea. It is suggested that in Syriac Christianities Eusebius? authorial persona, as portrayed in the works by him or attributed to him, was considerably influenced by the traditions about his relation to other authors and members of the Empire and its church.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.ORGANIZADORES: Hugh A.G. Houghton; M. L. Davies; Markus Vinzent

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Among the Christians said to have been martyred during the Diocletianic Persecution, one of the best known nowadays is the man who was executed for tearing down an imperial writing said to contain the order for the destruction of Christian scriptures. Scholars regularly refer to him when analysing late-antique texts which refer to some similar incidents, suggesting a widespread resonance of this martyrology during Late Antiquity. The article assesses the influence of the narrative on fourth- and fifth-century Christian and Rabbinic references to a paradigmatic deadly incident linked to disrespect towards authoritative writing or flouting of the order for book destruction, using a passage in a homily by Theodotus of Ancyra as a case-study. The plausibility and veracity of the earliest sources on the incident and of its incorporation into late-antique collective memory in the Roman Empire and beyond is assessed.

The plausibility and veracity of the earliest sources on the incident and of its incorporation into late-antique collective memory in the Roman Empire and beyond is assessed.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Dialogues in Syriac translation: Theodotus of Ancyra Contra Nestorium
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Dialogues in Syriac translation: Theodotus of Ancyra Contra Nestorium

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Syriac Intellectual Culture in Late Antiquity: Translation, Transmission, and Influence

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: This paper presents some initial finds on the Syriac reception of Theodotus of Ancyra?s works, written in the decades around the First Council of Ephesus (AD 431) on Christological polemics. The main evidence is his treatise against Nestorius, an early example of refutation of excerpts presented as dialogue, which is preserved only in a Syriac translation found in one manuscript, which A. van Roey dated to 650-60. Theodotus was mentioned in the ecclesiastical histories about the Council of Ephesus, and often cited as a theological authority alongside, for example, Cyril of Alexandria, Proclus Constantinopolitanus and Acacius Melitensis (e.g. by Severus Antiochenus). Previous scholarship revealed the transmission and reception of Cyril?s works and ideas in Syriac, and addressed the Syriac evidence for Proclus?s homiletics and the theological disputes in his see and Armenia. The sources often reflect their canonical status, which Theodotus, whose influence in Syriac Christianity faded, did not gain. For example, only excerpts or wrongly attributed homilies were translated into Arabic. Thus, analysing his works can show more clearly the links of early Syriac translations of Christological polemical treatises with the contemporary reception of historiographical works, synodical minutes and collections of documents, and the relevance for Syriac theology of the arguments the treatises contain. Furthermore, it indicates the connection of Christological dialogues with florilegia and refutations of excerpts, and the spread of dialogues as a form of invective, that included the writing of spurious (e.g. Ps.-Cyril, CPG 5433) and later works (e.g. Abu Qurrah?s acerbic polemics).

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Perspectives on Language and Culture in Early Christianity ? International Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The intellectual landscape of the Classical world was radically altered by the rise and spread of Christianity. In particular, the linguistic horizon of Western scholars was considerably widened through direct acquaintance with the Old Testament languages (Hebrew and Aramaic). Because of these and other socio-cultural changes, the period of late antiquity and early Christianity is a very interesting one with regard to reflection on language and culture. Addressing itself to an audience of scholars in a wide variety of fields (philology, theology, philosophy, language sciences, history of ideas), this international conference will approach the general theme of "language and culture in early Christianity" from a content- as well as a context-oriented perspective.

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.INSTITUICAO-PROMOTORA: Institute for Textual Scholarship and Electronic Editing

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Among the Christians said to have been martyred during the Diocletianic Persecution, the man who was executed for tearing an imperial writing said to contain the order for the destruction of Christian scriptures is one of the best known nowadays. Scholars regularly refer to it when analysing late-antique texts which refer to some similar incidents, suggesting a widespread resonance of this martyrology during Late Antiquity. The paper analyses the earliest known references, such as Lactantius Mort.pers. 13 and Eusebius H.E. 8.2.4-5; 8.5, considering the polemic characterisation of imperial authority in their hagiographic and historiographic narratives, and comparing them with classical topoi of book-burning, related to concepts of language and the materiality of writing. The paper also assesses the influence of the narrative on later Christian and Rabbinic references to a paradigmatic deadly incident for disrespect to authoritative writing or flouting of orders of book destruction, as found for example in John Chrysostom, Basil of Caesarea, Theodotus of Ancyra and Midrash Esther. Bringing to bear the most recent finds in Roman Law on the First Persecution Edict, anti-Manichaean measures, and their enforcement, as well as current scholarship on hagiographic narratives, the paper concludes by discussing the plausibility and veracity of the earliest sources on the incident and of its incorporation into late-antique collective memory in the Roman Empire and beyond.

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The paper will briefly survey the diversity of Syriac traditions, the Patristic bias of the corpus, which is therefore unrepresentative of Syriac cultural traditions, and the wide timeframe of the manuscripts, in the context of their production and transmission. Many manuscripts and palimpsests are held by ?Western? libraries, but the catalogues are often deficient. Frequently, unknown texts and recensions are found in them, as well as in archaeological excavations, such as in Turfan, and in local archives, such as in Christian communities in Malabar and Kerala. Around the momentous contribution of Syriac manuscripts to conciliar studies and to scholarship on the Christological controversies, including their philosophical and political implications, the paper will show that an interdisciplinary research of Syriac manuscripts is essential for Patristics Studies.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Seven of Maximus the Confessor?s letters provide enough information on his involvement in a prolonged and multifaceted affair involving a group of female ascetics from Alexandria who had fled Egypt because of the Arab invasion. Scholars have disentangled significantly the chronology of the letters and of the cited events, the political motivations of the many named individuals from the capital, North Africa and Italy who were involved, and some of the religious opinions which the main players espoused. The incidents elicit, however, many other questions, especially related to the presentation of various perspectives on the Arab invasion which influenced the nuns to remain in exile and not return. It is now understood that Byzantine sources reflect a perception of the invasion which resorted mainly to images used on the long Persian occupation, and was also aware of the demise of Persia. Thus, at least in Palestine, toleration of religious difference and cooperation were presented as viable alternative. The paper focuses on the context in which Maximus refers to the nuns and implies that the life options for monophysite female ascetics in Egypt under Arab rule seemed worse than as exiles residing in coenobitic foundations in which the tenets of Christian orthodoxy required the exiled women to give up or repress some of the main precepts of their Christian faith. It compares the initial local willingness to accommodate suppressed deviant creeds, to the violent measures taken, after some months, against the Egyptian women, allegedly in reaction to their attempts to ostensively profess their views. The letters suggest that they were encouraged and began to proselytise and defend their identity despite the efforts of key aristocrats and church leaders in the Byzantine empire, with which Maximus was engaged on friendly or hostile terms. The paper considers the pastoral responsibilities Maximus had towards these women, and weights in the influence his theological and eccle

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Final Conference of the Kolleg-Forschergruppe ?Religious Individualization in Historical Perspective?

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Abstract: The short paper introduces the context of the writings and events analysed in the chapter of same title and points out aspects which have been neglected or have not yet been analysed in light of recent scholarship on late-antique historiography, epistolography, orality and the use of writing. It presents the recent findings about Eusebius? polemical literary output and the reception of his writings in Athanasius? works, which, by endorsing minority views advanced in them, recast them endorsing their historicity. Comparing with the literary narratives and papyrological evidence about the social presence of bishops in the provinces of the Roman Empire, the paper explains how the chapter contributed to the understanding of the truth-value of Eusebian ecclesiology, shedding light on lived Christian religions in Late Antiquity and especially nuancing the accounts about processes of its institutionalisation.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Narratives of synodical harmony and consensus in Late Antiquity
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Narratives of synodical harmony and consensus in Late Antiquity

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.INSTITUICAO-PROMOTORA: Max-Weber-Kolleg für kultur- und sozialwissenschaftliche Studien

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Roman and Christian identities and especially their processes of institutionalisation have often been related to the decision-making processes of select representative bodies, such as the Senates in Rome and Constantinople, and the synods. The project aims to show that the literary evidence provides little insight into the real processes and rituals of decision-making. Instead, the texts in manuscripts, papyri, epigraphy and other media provide information about the expectations about concepts and methods which could be associated to these groups and processes. In view of the evidence about the production, use, archival, transmission and translation of texts in Late Antiquity, the current research focus is on the options for using written media in what were predominantly oral cultures and on the choice of idiom and literary styles which engage with values that can be associated to the Roman Empire. The goal is a book on ?the authority of consensus in Late Antiquity?, focusing on expressions of unanimity which envisaged imperial readership. The production and use of narratives about consensus in Christian synods will probably be the leitmotiv. Particular attention will be given to the literature de facto or allegedly produced in the first half of the fifth-century about fourth-century and contemporary events. Emphasising that the texts were created, received and modified as part of various social and cultural contexts in which they were only a fraction of the narratives and values associated to its contents and authors, a number of examples will provide a composite picture of the values and expectations about the proceedings and their literary representations.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Early Christianity usually lumps together half a millennium or more of processes of religious individualisation and institutionalisation. This chronology supports a teleological narrative which by its very existence proves a number of religious tenets such as apostolic succession and the consensual religious and disciplinary dispute-resolution. Once elements of textual and material evidence which have a mediated semantic relation to reality are taken as historical narrative, reading the accounts at face value created and described fallaciously a number of processes and concepts of religious agency, individualisation, institutionalisation and ritual. Critical reading of spuria and analysis of their relation to the textual and archaeological evidence of the internal time of the narrative and of the moments of composition and edition sheds light on the reliability of, for example, the documents of Christian synods, showing processes of religious individualisation which elicit and are engendered by them. This chapter tackles the Coptic Acts of Ephesus as a case-study of the literary and mainly historiographic character of late-antique synodical documentation.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Spicing Nonnus up: commercial and religious crossroads and Nonnus? representation of the East
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Spicing Nonnus up: commercial and religious crossroads and Nonnus? representation of the East

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Nonnus of Panopolis in Context IV: Poetry at the crossroads

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The late-antique literary representation of Indian culture was steeped in classical narratives and religious traditions. It had developed parallel to the successes and reverses of Hellenistic and Roman imperial military, economic and cultural endeavours beyond their Eastern frontiers. Features of contemporary Indian culture and a more realistic representation of social and religious characteristics are little attested in Greek and Latin literature, as if the socially accepted cliches had been little affected by the direct or mediated Roman contact with India. In Nonnus? time, also the spread of religious and philosophical thoughts and practices, such as Christian and Manichaean, connected these regions. They used linguistic registers selectively, and their polemical literature engaged with Greek erudite and intellectual discourses, which contributed for the literary representation of outsiders with clear dichotomies. Among a wide range of religious practices and beliefs, the literarily more visible Christian groups in India and Egypt regarded one another as heretical, reflecting the spread of Eastern theologies beyond the Persian frontier. At the same time, in the urban context of Nonnus and his public, Indian cultural elements were widespread, as shown by recent studies of the archaeological and textual evidence. They point to regular direct trade of Indian products in urban Egypt. The paper will assess Nonnus? representation of Eastern foreigners taking into consideration the likelihood that his urban audiences were familiar with Indian culture and aware of tensions between the processes of religious individualisation in the East, especially in India, and in the local urban milieu.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The continuity and recognition enjoyed by communities which identified themselves with notions condemned in fourth- and fifth-century church councils can be related directly to the concomitant and interrelated processes of consolidation of historiographic narratives about Christian synods, their materialisation in imperial monuments and texts, and the cultural acceptance of theological and political values and categories. Focusing on the Council of Nicaea, the continuous presence of local Arian communities in Constantinople until the seventh century and the incidents of identification and estrangement with ?Arians? involving John Chrysostom, Leo the Great and Justin will be briefly reviewed. Then, the paper analyses the use of ?Arian? liturgies in the East and the criteria with which they could be identified as orthodox or not. For this, the focus falls on the variant readings of the ?Ekthesis? of the ?Didascalia CCXVIII Patrum Nicaenum? (CPG 2298) and the prayers attributed to Serapion of Thmuis. The paper concludes by suggesting that the simplification of the narrative landscape by the political and ethnic fragmentation of the Eastern Roman empire following the Persian and Arabic expansions was decisive for the stabilisation of a narrative of the early church councils.

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Conference: Migration and Mobility Across the Roman-Persian Frontier, 3rd-7th c. A.D.

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This paper will present the efforts of some fourth and fifth-century bishops to convert peoples in Sasanid Persia to their Christian faith. It will compare the evangelising tactics and the representations of the Church of an Empire of John Chrysostom, Eusebius of Caesarea and Marutha of Maipherkat. Analysing their target audiences and the reception of their writings will be linked to patterns of migration primarily of peoples from the Roman Empire settling abroad, the local presence of Jewish-Christianities and other lived religions also found in the Roman East, and to a growing relevance of Roman political arguments also among Iranians, especially in the newer cities. The paper will then discuss how mobility influenced religious belongings which could inform processes of socio-political individualisation. It will focus on the organisation and narrative representation of the Council of Seleucia-Ctesiphon. It will point out how it casts a part of Persian Christianity as an imperial church which can assist Sassanid rule and through it be given further means to oppose its religious enemies. This will be put into the context of the production and circulation of manuscripts with Syriac translations of works by or attributed to Eusebius and Athanasius on ecclesiology and historiography. The paper will bring to bear contemporary patterns of temporary seasonal migration characteristic of the Indo-Roman and Indo-Persian trade where they help to show the relevance of long term migration with some degree of settlement and cultural resonance for the impact of religious information conveyed by the mobility of writings and people.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Consensus and unanimous decision-making seem to be imperial and spiritual values which have their place in the historiographic and theological portrayal of Empires as they should be, in a context of very complex engagements of religious agencies and power dispute between Christian leaders, bishops, monks, monasteries, ascetics and domestic monastics. When opting for the material medium of writing, established editorial and codicological technologies were employed to create historiographies to be read by the standards of the culture of a Christian Roman Empire. These tools included the exegetical and polemical arsenal to which had contributed much masters such as Origen, Eusebius and Theodoret of Cyrrhus and the scriptoria they had around them.

When opting for the material medium of writing, established editorial and codicological technologies were employed to create historiographies to be read by the standards of the culture of a Christian Roman Empire. These tools included the exegetical and polemical arsenal to which had contributed much masters such as Origen, Eusebius and Theodoret of Cyrrhus and the scriptoria they had around them.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Vineyards, Wine, Women, and Writing: Materiality in the Communication of 6th Century Eastern Monastic Settlements

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: International Medieval Congress (IMC)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In P. Naqlun I 12, a scribe wrote a letter by bishop Nikolaos to a comes Basileios on the ownership of vineyards and the desire for a reply of a certain lady, kyra Ioannia. Then he changed the style of his writing and added his own remarks about embarrassing gifts and payment. The papyrus presents various scenarios in which the materiality of the written media was relevant for the spatial self-perception of the monastery as a self-proclaimed universal node of economic and religious interaction. This paper will examine the representation of monastic places in the flow of information, goods and people, how this affected its members, and the reception of their religious and cultural agency in supplying material commodities such as healthcare and elite burial.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Alexandria in control? The written reception and oral transmission of Festal Letters in the light of fifth-century papyri
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Alexandria in control? The written reception and oral transmission of Festal Letters in the light of fifth-century papyri

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XVIII. International Conference on Patristic Studies

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
https://oxfordpatristics.blogspot.com/search?q=frenkel
Abstract
Contemporary remarks about the circulation of Festal Letters in the fourth and fifth centuries are usually taken at face value and it is assumed that copies of the letters reached each year all dioceses and communities in Egypt. This is not corroborated by the papyri. They cast doubt on the use of writing, its efficacy and the relevance and impact of the pronouncements of the bishop of Alexandria. The papyri and ostraca show a multifaceted textual culture in which more often than not letters were edited and interpolated. At the same time, papyri like P. Vindob. K 10157, show the prestige of the format of the festal letter as a vehicle for theological teaching, in that case of Origenistic and Evagrian vein, which Cyril would probably have criticised rather than espoused. Thus, rather than descriptions, the claims about the circulation of the letters should be read as injunctions or pleas for allied clerics and religious people to spread the content of that year as efficaciously as possible in their zone of influence, and thus, probably, orally and in translation into local languages and theological parlance.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Religious dissent, civil wars and the end of Antiquity
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Religious dissent, civil wars and the end of Antiquity

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Religiöse (De-)Legitimationsansätze von Gewalt in der Antike

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
The paper analyses the participation of Christian leaders, especially bishops in civil wars, focusing on their literary representation as advisors of would-be-usurpers. Perhaps the best known case is Maximus the Confessor?s relation with Gregory, exarch of Africa, for which he was prosecuted for weakening the cohesion of the Roman Empire and exposing it to the Arab invasion. The late-antique and Byzantine literature on the case was used by historians such as E. Gibbons to corroborate their teleological understanding of the changes in the Roman Empire. This paper will clarify the classical and religious traditions of the literary representation of religious leaders qua political advisers and question the scope of their influence. It will also discuss the prominence of similar religious arguments in imperial identity, as reflected in Roman legislation that envisaged the confiscation of property, physical punishments and exile of dissidents. While the enforcement of such measures can be linked to wider economic and social changes, and the efficiency of force in bringing about conversions or recantations was questioned, it will be argued that orthodox Christianity was seen as legitimising violence which would be leading to stability and wealth of the empire.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Diese Tagung soll Perspektiven der Historisierung von religiöser Gewalt erproben. Viele Beiträge konzentrieren sich auf die Zeit von 650 bis 1450, doch sind auch Perspektiven auf die Zeit davor und die Zeit danach willkommen. Sie sollen durch den Vergleich Hinweise auf den Wandel von religiöser Gewalt ermöglichen.
The conflicting narratives suggest that no violence was conceived as intrinsically religious, and it befell the historiographic gaze to identify it. This does not deny the existence of religious violence in Late Antiquity. Rather, it signals that linking violence and religion was used to cast the character in a better or worse light. Violence done for the sake of the correct religion, that is, the orthodoxy advocated for in the work, is acceptable, just as therapeutic pain, which a doctor employs knowing how much is needed and necessary. More often than not, however, violence especially when de-scribed with meticulous attention to brutal details, was mentioned to signal the corrupt state of its perpetrator or conceiver. Associating the violence to religious purposes usually linked to erroneous beliefs distanced him further from the images of ideal human being and especially of good ruler.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Hellenistic dramatic metres and performance practices in popular and polemic late antique poetry
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Hellenistic dramatic metres and performance practices in popular and polemic late antique poetry

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: VI Semana de Estudos sobre o Período Helenístico: a produção dramática no período helenístico e sua influência na literatura greco-latina posterior
DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.LOCAL-DA-APRESENTACAO: Prédio Antonio Candido de Mello e Souza, Faculdade de Filosofia, Letras e Ciências Humanas, USP

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Little attested in the late-antique poetry transmitted in manuscripts, the metres of Hellenistic drama seem to have been widely used in oral and written Greek poetry of the second to fourth century AD. They are attested in several papyri, numerous inscriptions and a number of passages refer to their use in poems which range from songs of sailors to theurgic polemical statements of faith. The paper focuses on ancient quotations and references to Arius? poems, especially his use of sotadean verses, and analyses the scholarly background of Athanasius? and Gregory of Nyssa?s derogatory remarks about their performance. Thus, it engages with scholarship about modern histories of Greek tragedy and their views about its seeming pervasive influence, pantomimes, mimes, ?subliterary? texts and metre-symbolism.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Little attested in the late-antique poetry transmitted in manuscripts, the metres of Hellenistic drama seem to have been widely used in oral and written Greek poetry of the second to fourth century AD. They are attested in several papyri, numerous inscriptions and a number of passages refer to their use in poems which range from songs of sailors to theurgic polemical statements of faith. The paper focuses on ancient quotations and references to Arius? poems, especially his use of sotadean verses, and analyses the scholarly background of Athanasius? and Gregory of Nyssa?s derogatory remarks about their performance. Thus, it engages with scholarship about modern histories of Greek tragedy and their views about its seeming pervasive influence, pantomimes, mimes, ?subliterary? texts and metre-symbolism.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: O papel da poesia litúrgica judaica e seu espaço de performance
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: The role of Jewish liturgical poetry and its space of performance

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Círculo de Reflexão sobre Judaísmo Contemporâneo #28;
DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.LOCAL-DA-APRESENTACAO: Casa do Povo, Rua Três Rios 252; Cidade: Bom Retiro

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O papel da poesia litúrgica judaica e seu espaço de performance ao longo do tempo nem sempre foram iguais. Mesmo conhecidos e entoados até hoje, existe uma lacuna sobre as circunstâncias nas quais esses textos se desenvolveram na antiguidade e ganharam aceitação. A partir de qual ponto e porque surgiu a poesia ritual judaica? Até onde se estende sua influência? Ricos em metáforas, analogias e outras figuras de linguagem, os piyutim no judaísmo vão além da religiosidade: são importantes em diálogos internos, como no desenvolvimento da literatura judaica. Mas durante os séculos VI e VII, época de muitas trocas culturais e religiosas, foram relevantes também para produções de outros grupos.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
The role of Jewish liturgical poetry and its space of performance over time have not always been the same. Although some are still used nowadays, current practices do not reflect well the circumstances are in which these texts developed and gained acceptance in Antiquity. At what point and why did Jewish ritual poetry develop? How far does its influence go?

Rich in metaphors, analogies and other figures of speech, the relevance of piyutim goes beyond their religious dimension. They offer important evidence of changes in Jewish literature and the development of cultural identities in late-antique Palestine.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Network analysis of late-antique synodical documentation and the reception of the Council of Ephesus (431)
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Network analysis of late-antique synodical documentation and the reception of the Council of Ephesus (431)

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: The Connected Past 2018

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Concomitant to the rise of the notion of Fathers of the Church and the authority of (some of) their writings in the late fourth and fifth centuries, Christian discourses developed strategies to access information of all periods and places. The relevance of epistolary networks in the literary, pastoral and polemical activities has been shown in a number of case studies, focused on authors such as Theodoret of Cyrrhus, Ambrose of Milan and Leo of Rome and the papyrological evidence of bishops and monasteries in Egypt. Also florilegia and catenae have likewise been explored as instruments to establish networks with past concepts. The availability of documents and existence of archives, often designated in geographical or institutional terms, has generally been taken for granted, but is increasingly contested. This paper will analyse the credibility of written and oral information that allowed the collection of narratives about Christian synods, considering in spatial networks also the influence of the letter-bearers. It will show the ?private? character of the collections, organised as hermeneutical and exegetical tools, discussing the ranked distances of the spatial networks of their polemical and pastoral use, using the texts about the proceedings of the Council of Ephesus in 431 in Greek, Coptic and Syriac as a case-study.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Concomitant to the rise of the notion of Fathers of the Church and the authority of (some of) their writings in the late fourth and fifth centuries, Christian discourses developed strategies to access information of all periods and places. The relevance of epistolary networks in the literary, pastoral and polemical activities has been shown in a number of case studies, focused on authors such as Theodoret of Cyrrhus, Ambrose of Milan and Leo of Rome and the papyrological evidence of bishops and monasteries in Egypt. Also florilegia and catenae have likewise been explored as instruments to establish networks with past concepts. The availability of documents and existence of archives, often designated in geographical or institutional terms, has generally been taken for granted, but is increasingly contested. This paper will analyse the credibility of written and oral information that allowed the collection of narratives about Christian synods, considering in spatial networks also the influence of the letter-bearers. It will show the ?private? character of the collections, organised as hermeneutical and exegetical tools, discussing the ranked distances of the spatial networks of their polemical and pastoral use, using the texts about the proceedings of the Council of Ephesus in 431 in Greek, Coptic and Syriac as a case-study.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
This colloquium will provide an informal and friendly platform for scholars and students interested in late-antique, early medieval and Byzantine councils to exchange ideas freely about synodical procedure and decision-making, the redaction of proceedings and historiographies, norms and legislations related to synods and councils.

Speakers include:
Marek Jankowiak (University of Oxford)
Richard Price (Heythrop College, University of London)
Rosamond McKitterick (University of Cambridge)
Thomas Graumann (University of Cambridge)
Mark Smith (University of Cambridge)
Philip Wood (Aga Khan University)

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONC.TITULO: Tradução e comentário do Praktikos de Evágrio Pôntico
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONC.TITULO-INGLES: Translation and commentary of Evagrius Ponticus' Praktikos

DETALHAMENTO-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONCL.NOME-DO-ORIENTADO: Benedito de Pina Almeida Prado Neto

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Recepção, tradução e transmissão de textos gregos em siríaco, copta e etiópico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Esse projeto tem como objetivo principal a tradução e comentário com enfoque histórico-filológico do Praktikos de Evágrio. Ao longo da tradução, a análise visa a alcançar outros objetivos:	
1) o levantamento bibliográfico de estudos recentes sobre a organização da obra em kephalaia, para rever a contribuição de Evágrio nas literaturas tanto do ocidente quanto do oriente;	
2) entender questões de filiação literária, religiosa e filosófica propostas explicitamente, como na passagem do epílogo do Praktikos (GUILLAUMONT,1971b, p. 712-713), em que se pede a intercessão de Gregório de Nazianzo, ou pela semelhança de léxico e arranjo de palavras, sobretudo entre Evágrio e Gregório de Nazianzo e entre Máximo Confessor e Evágrio;	
3) cotejar as traduções e estudos desta obra, considerada preliminar e fundamental no corpus evagriano, que, apesar de sua relevância na transmissão de conceitos neoplatônicos e estoicos para o pensamento do medievo ocidental, continua desconhecida na academia brasileira; 	
4) elaboração de um pequeno glossário dos termos comuns às obras de Evágrio e da filosofia ateniense clássica cujo significado na obra de Evágrio difere do original.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONC.TITULO: Presença clássica nas literaturas orais brasileiras e a recepção das tradições orais africanas em português brasileiro
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONC.TITULO-INGLES: Classical presence in Brazilian oral literatures and the reception of African oral traditions in Brazilian Portuguese

DETALHAMENTO-DE-OUTRAS-ORIENTACOES-CONCL.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Política de Apoio à Permanência e Formação Estudantil ? USP

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Esse projeto propõe pesquisar as literaturas orais em português brasileiro para analisar a presença das tradições africanas e clássicas greco-romanas, seja nos meios usados para criar narrativas em performances, seja na presença de micro ou macro-estruturas daquelas, tais quais símiles, cenas típicas e narrativas (ou mitos). Neste ano, os objetivos principais são desenvolver os critérios e métodos e iniciar o levantamento das literaturas orais brasileiras preservadas em acervos áudio-visuais e a comparação com as práticas atuais.
